 STAFF APPRAISAL REPORT KYRGYZ REPUBLIC RURAL FINANCE PROJECT I. THE AGRICULTURAL SECTOR A. THE FARMING SECTOR 1.01 Agriculture is important in the Kyrgyz economy as it accounts for about 30 percent of GDP and approximately one-third of employment. An additional 10 percent of the labor force is employed in agriculture-related industries, mostly agribusiness enterprises. Agribusiness activities add to the overall impact of agriculture to account for over 50 percent of GDP. 1.02 Irrigation is critical for agriculture, covering over 80 percent of arable land. The main crops grown are wheat, barley, maize, cotton, tobacco, sugar beet, sunflower, potatoes, vegetables, fruits, and fodder crops. Winter wheat is the dominant cereal crop, accounting for over 40 percent of the area usually under grains. Livestock production contributes significantly to total agricultural production. The major livestock products are meat, milk, wool and eggs. 1.03 Agricultural output in the last two years has shown significant recovery. Indeed, recovery in agricultural output in 1996 exceeded expectations. Agricultural output increased by 13 percent in real terms, compared to the overall GDP growth of 5 percent in 1996. The major sources of agricultural growth were wheat, potato, cotton, and vegetables. This recovery in agricultural growth was largely due to expansion in cultivated area, changes in cropping patterns (shift from fodder to grain production), and favorable weather conditions. Also recent farm studies indicate that profitability in some of these crops and dairy farming has improved and the prospects for further improvements appear good in the coming years as markets become more competitive. Crop profitability is improving much faster in small private farms than on large public sector farms. Most public sector farms continue to operate with losses. Also, most livestock production remains generally less profitable than crop production, largely because prices for most livestock products have remained depressed. 1.04 Despite the implementation of the ongoing economic reforms and the recent recovery in output, farm productivity and profitability continue to face major constraints. The constraints include limited supply of critical inputs, lack of competitive markets, lack of appropriate technical packages and advisory services for private farmers, lack of credit for private farmers, and existence of inefficient farm structures. The last constraint is particularly important because it is a precondition for improved farm productivity and profitability. Farm restructuring is still an unfinished agenda. To date, farm restructuring has taken a variety of forms which include the emergence of: (a) private individual peasant farms (23,000); (b) family farming associations (1,500); collective farms (540); state farms (320); and joint-stock farm enterprises (15). By the end of 1996, it was estimated that private sector farms accounted for over 60 percent of the land held by agricultural enterprises. The remainder was still in the hands of public sector farms. 1.05 To sustain and accelerate the apparent recovery in agriculture, Government needs to address at least the following four issues: (a) farm restructuring, which has slowed down, should be accelerated to promote the emergence of efficient farms; (b) price and market distortions should be eliminated (especially at the local level and any inter-oblast trade restrictions); (c) access to credit by private farm
 2 and agribusiness enterprises should be ensured to promote farm investments and the development of competitive farm markets; and (d) provision of technical advisory services and new productivity- enhancing technologies should be given high priority. 1.06 Despite the recent recovery in agricultural growth, poverty has increased significantly over the last three years. The proportion of households considered poor increased from 40 percent in 1993 to 49 percent in 1996. The poverty gap index, which measures the difference between the poverty line and the household's actual expenditure levels, doubled from 12 percent in 1993 to 24 percent in 1996. The proportion of the very poor households, those which spend less than half of their poverty line expenditures, virtually remained the same at 25 percent over the period. Poverty alleviation will require specific measures which target the poor as primary beneficiaries. The proposed project's Small Farmers' Credit Outreach Program (SFCOP) would target households at, or slightly above the poverty line, while Kyrgyz Agricultural Credit Corporation's (KAFC) lending program and Asian Development Bank's (ADB) credit unions program would be exclusively targeted at households well above the poverty line. The very poor households would be targeted by the proposed Kyrgyz People's Initiative Project which is being prepared for financing by the Bank and other donors. B. AGRIBUSINESS SECTOR 1.07 Since independence in 1992, agro-processing has dramatically declined in the Kyrgyz Republic. The sector remains in a serious crisis, despite government privatization effort which has resulted in the emergence of numerous private agribusinesses. A survey (1996) of agribusiness enterprises conducted during the preparation of this project, revealed that the expected surge in private agribusiness activities, leading to the development of competitive markets, has not materialized out of the recent liberalization and privatization programs of the Government. Emerging private enterprises are facing considerable commercial risks and relatively high costs for goods and services (including finance) which weaken their scope to participate and compete in markets. The weak financial markets have been deleterious to the development of private agribusiness in the country. The poor state of the banking sector has inhibited the capacity of private agribusiness enterprises to respond effectively to the production and market opportunities being created by liberalization policies. Private small agribusiness enterprises have very limited access to formal sources of credit and face high collateral requirements and limited term finance options. Also equally limiting is the dearth of agribusiness management skills as a result of the past dominance of processing and marketing state enterprises. 1.08 The agribusiness survey (1996) also revealed the following to be the most critical issues in the agribusiness sector in the Kyrgyz Republic today: (a) Lack of working capital for raw materials. Agro-processing plants or enterprises do not have cash to pay farmers for their produce during the harvest/marketing season. This has led farmers to sell their produce to small traders for cash or bartered goods, leaving most agro-processing plants without raw materials; (b) Lack of capital for renovation of equipment and machinery. Machinery and equipment replacement or renovation is required in most of the agro-processing plants, especially in food processing industries, to improve efficiency and product quality; (c) Lack of capital for financing inventory and receivables. The time required to hold a finished product in storage prior to actual sale is relatively longer in the Kyrgyz market
 3 where market information is not readily available to potential buyers. This requires financing or else it forces the producing firm to sell on cash basis; and (d) Lack of working capital for farm inputs supply. Major farm inputs, like fertilizers, seeds, and livestock drugs are generally not traded or retailed by local stockists or dealers and distributors because of lack of working capital. 1.09 The proposed project would address some of these issues by providing eligible private agribusiness enterprises with access to short term loans.
 4 II. RURAL FINANCE SYSTEM A. THE FINANCIAL SECTOR 2.01 The financial sector in the Kyrgyz Republic suffers from the legacy of the Soviet past and the early transitional efforts. The banking structure has until recently been dominated by four former state-owned banks -- Agroprom, Promstroi, AKB Kyrgyzstan and Elbank -- that accounted for 80 percent of the banking sector assets and were highly insolvent due to bad debt. Slowly growing segment of newer, market-oriented banks are still quite fragile. The newly emerging capital markets are insufficient to meet the needs of a market system which is developing rapidly in response to the successful enterprise privatization. At present, the Kyrgyz banking system consists of NBK, the central bank, and 16 commercial banks. There are also a number of non-bank financial institutions. These include 17 investment funds, 30 insurance companies, a stock exchange (KSE), a Coupon (privatization) Trading Center (CTC), and one significant state-owned and two smaller private pension funds. 2.02 After the break up of the Soviet Union, inflation in the Kyrgyz Republic accelerated rapidly and, over a relatively short period, the real value of bank deposits was massively eroded by negative real interest rates. Following the introduction of the national currency, the Som, in 1993, considerable success has been achieved in macro-financial stability. The traditional policy of directed credits to enterprises and agriculture continued officially until early 1994. Most of this lending covered losses or was to maintain employment and was not undertaken on the basis of commercial criteria and was largely funded by the NBK. During 1994, deposit and credit interest rates were liberalized, directed credits were discontinued, refinance credit auctions were temporarily suspended, and domestic bank financing of the budget deficit was sharply curtailed. The tight monetary stance since 1994 succeeded in bringing inflation down from over 1000 percent per year in 1992, to around 35 percent in 1996. Interest rates have followed a similar path, with real interest rates declining from over 200 percent in 1994 to around 25 percent in 1996. 2.03 The successful implementation of the stabilization program has revealed the structural and financial weaknesses of the state enterprises, and at the same time, uncovered the portfolio problems of the commercial banks. The decisive tightening of monetary policy not only cut the commercial banks' access to NBK resources but also uncovered the extent of bad loans in the sector. In 1995, the non-performing loans represented almost the entire portfolio of Agroprom as well as Elbank, the former Sberbank. In AKB Kyrgyzstan and Promstroi, non-performing loans accounted for more than half of their portfolios. The survival of the big formerly state-owned banks has been possible only because of specially negotiated terms for the NBK debt and because of exemption from prudential regulations. The intermediation role of the financial system has been severely constrained by these non-performing loans. 2.04 There has also been a wide-spread lack of confidence in the financial system. Past experience has been dominated by dramatic loss in the real value of deposits and by periodic instances of difficulties in withdrawing deposits. The failure of Kyrgyz banks to mobilize deposits is clearly linked to the sector's insolvency problems. A further factor inhibiting deposit mobilization has been the practice, until recently, of seizing the deposits of those believed to be in arrears on tax payments. In sum, the existing financial system has until recently been incapable of performing the fundamental role of mobilizing deposits and transforming those into loans. B. THE FINANCIAL SECTOR REFORM PROGRAM 2.05 Following successful stabilization and major reforms in the key real sectors, it became clear that, at this stage of the country's economic transformation process, a more stable and efficient financial sector,
 5 with an effective banking system at its core, would be essential to help sustain macroeconomic stability, stimulate savings mobilization, support output recovery and expansion, and enhance the development of the private sector. 2.06 A comprehensive Financial Sector Reform Program, therefore, supported by a Financial Sector Adjustment Credit (FfNSAC) from IDA (US$45 million) was launched in June, 1996. The Reform Program supported by FINSAC focuses on: (i) the creation of a policy and regulatory environment conducive to the sound growth of a competitive and efficient private banking system; (ii) the liquidation of the two dominant and insolvent state-owned banks: Agroprombank and Elbank, which, through their practices, stifle the growth of their young private competitors; (iii) the downsizing and financial restructuring through private re-capitalization of two large and insolvent former state banks: Promstroi and AKB Kyrgyzstan Banks; (iv) the establishment of a temporary Debt Resolution Agency (DEBRA) to help collect, restructure, sell or write off the old non-performing loans, and thus accelerate enterprise restructuring or liquidation in the process; and (v) the creation of a regulatory and supervisory framework, and supporting policies and infrastructure, for the development and growth of emerging non-bank financial institutions (NBFIs). 2.07 The successful implementation of this Reform Program, already underway, will lead to the creation of an initially smaller, but more solvent and efficient private banking system, capable of providing a broader range of financial services to both borrowers and savers. In the rural areas, Agroprom bank and the existing system of poorly-managed directed credit programs will initially be superseded by a better managed, temporary rural finance system, funded by budgetary resources and donor assistance, and over the longer term, by a commercially viable thus sustainable, system of rural banking and cooperatives. In the enterprise sector, private enterprises will be served by smaller private sector banks, better regulated by sound prudential norms, and equipped with sound credit policies and trained staff. The establishment of equity markets is already underway, and will over time lead to more active trading of the shares of private enterprises, thus contributing to better enterprise governance. The development and enforcement of a sound regulatory and supervisory framework will enhance the efficiency and security of financial institutions; help restore public confidence in the financial system; and encourage the emergence and expansion of non-bank financial institutions (NBFIs). C. THE RURAL FINANCE SYSTEM 2.08 Until 1994, rural financing was dominated by the state owned Agroprombank. The demise of this institution has left the rural sector without an institutional lender. In response to this void, Government has decided to establish a commercially oriented and operationally autonomous credit agency, the Kyrgyz Agricultural Finance Corporation (KAFC), and to begin the long-term development of a community-based ruralfinance system (para. 3.01). 2.09 In the wake of the Agroprombank's closing in 1994, Government has channeled "credit" to farmers through the Regional Administration (oblast and rayon akiamiat), whereby loans have been administered by regional and district authorities. Later in 1995, several Rural Credit Cooperatives (RCCs) were established among farmers under the directive of the Ministry of Agriculture and Food (MAF). These approaches have had dismal results, in terms of credit reaching the target groups and of loan repayment. Most of the funds were channeled to state and collective farms which have close relations with the local administration. Private farmers have had no access to this credit. The RCCs are not viable as social and economic entities. They do not command member loyalty as they are regarded as part of the local government.
 6 2.10 In addition to the Government credit program, seven donor-sponsored rural credit schemes are active. These include schemes sponsored by TACIS, US-Kyrgyz Joint Agricultural Commission, CARITASlHELVETAS, GTZ, FINCA, Kyrgyz Agricultural Company, and an IDA-sponsored pilot Peoples Development Project. These schemes, except GTZ, have concentrated on short-term lending for seasonal inputs. The total amount of lending under these schemes is estimated at less than US$1.5 million per season. These various schemes have adopted diverse mechanisms for lending, recovering loans, and managing risks. Lending through groups (as opposed to group lending) is the preferred mechanism among the schemes. All schemes are achieving commendable loan recoveries, ranging between 70 and 100 percent. The scope and geographical coverage of each credit scheme is extremely limited. The total amount of informal credit is unknown. It is, however, estimated that less than 12 percent of the private farmers are currently participating in the donor-sponsored credit schemes. 2.11 While reasonable progress is being made, under the donor-sponsored schemes, to establish informal and formal credit organizations, no attention has been given to the promotion of savings mobilization. Consequently, FINCA and the Asian Development Bank, have had to start from scratch in their attempt to promote voluntary savings and credit groups in the form of "village banks" and credit unions, respectively. 2.12 Some private farmers are using informal and semi-formal credit mechanisms for procuring farm inputs and working capital. These include, trader-provided credit in form of inputs which are repaid with pre-negotiated shares of the production of a farm product; farmer to farmer credit in cash or kind to enable poorer farmers procure essential farm inputs; and government-provided credit in-kind (fertilizers, seed, fuel) in exchange for delivery of wheat at harvest. 2.13 Superior credit repayment performance, under the various credit schemes, is associated with individual borrowing within groups which have been voluntarily established to provide individual members with access to institutional credit. Such groups include village or regional farmers' associations and credit groups. Credit repayment tends to improve when credit is offered and used as part of a technical package being sponsored by a "partnership of stakeholders" (e.g., farmers, credit agency, and farm extension service staff). Similarly, credit repayment performance tends to improve when individual loan applications are screened and endorsed, and repayment is enforced by a self- selected farmer group. This approach appears to mitigate the problems of imperfect borrower information and repayment enforcement. Groups established voluntarily are more cohesive (in the sociological sense) and share a higher degree of mutual trust than those established under covert duress, for example, the RCCs groups. 2.14 To succeed the credit schemes or local intermediaries initially must inculcate and enforce a "credit -repayment-culture" among the borrowing group to dispel the legacy of rampant non-repayment culture under the Agroprombank and the government credit programs. This process requires the adoption of effective repayment mechanisms and training of members. Threats to cut off borrower's future access to credit and peer pressure have proved to be effective sanctions to induce prompt and full repayment. 2.15 Provision of credit-in-kind appears to be a popular and effective mechanism for credit risk management among the schemes. Several credit schemes with superior recovery rates have adopted this mechanism. Joint and several guarantees or group responsibility for each other's loan does not appear to be popular or consistent with the Kyrgyz culture.
 7 2.16 Barter-based lending makes the lending interest rate structure less transparent. Some government commodity-based credit schemes have (implicit) high real interest rates which farmers have been willingly paying. Nominal annual interest rates charged by various rural credit schemes ranged between 12 and 39 percent during the 1995/96 crop season. It is noteworthy that some of these rates were positive in real terms and yet they did not adversely affect credit recovery rates, given the prevailing state of generally low farm profitability. The interest rates indicate the scope for positive interest rates as a few credit schemes were charging interest rates in excess of the inflation rate (35.0 percent) in 1996. The wide variations in lending interest rate among the rural credit schemes also indicates the presence of market segmentation within the rural finance system in the country. This is mainly because most credit schemes are location-specific and are surrounded by imperfect information. 2.17 Despite the impressive growth of farmers' associations (82 in 1996) in the last two years, most of them are not yet ready to function as effective financial intermediaries. For them to assume this role, intensive training of their voluntary staff and establishment of satisfactory accounting systems would be absolutely necessary. Lenders, like KAFC, should help with this training if they want to make use of these associations as intermediaries. D. GOVERNMENT STRATEGY FOR RURAL FINANCE 2.18 The findings of a Rural Finance Survey (1996) conducted during the preparation of this project, indicate that prospects for establishing a commercially viable rural finance system are good. The process would require a combination of "top-down" and "bottom-up" approach. In 1996, the State Commission on Rural Finance, endorsed a Rural Finance Strategy (prepared by an inter-agency Working Group with IDA technical assistance) which embraces this approach. In the short-term, Government has established a new interim credit agency, the KAFC, to manage the delivery of credit to the nascent private farming and agribusiness sectors during the transition. KAFC will be professionally managed and will operate with full autonomy through an independent Board of Directors. In the medium and long-term, Government intends to establish an institutional framework for providing financial services to rural communities on a commercially sustainable basis. This intention will be achieved through the promotion of community-based and managed financial institutions. These community financial institutions will be operated on the basis of cooperative principles, emphasizing self-help, democracy, and cost- effectiveness. Technical assistance will be required for KAFC and the community financial institutions. The proposed project would be the first phase for implementing this strategy. E. RATIONALE FOR IDA INVOLVEMENT 2.19 IDA's Country Assistance Strategy (CAS), approved by the Board during the presentation of the Agricultural Privatization and Enterprise Adjustment Credit (APEAC) on June 28, 1995 is focused on four priority areas: adjustment lending, agricultural/natural resource management, energy, and social sectors. Recovery in the agricultural sector is a critical element of IDA's assistance program for economic growth and poverty reduction. Within the CAS framework, IDA's assistance strategy for the rural sector consists of policy-based lending in support of structural reforms and investment lending in key sector. Structural reform credits with relevance to agriculture include: (a) the Privatization and Enterprise Sector Adjustment Credit (PESAC) which initiated liberalization of trade policies and the price system, and the improvement of the regulatory framework for private sector development; (b) the APEAC which deepens market and pricing liberalization in agriculture and fosters the development of competitive markets through enterprise privatization and private sector development; (c) an Institutional Development Fund (IDF) grant to facilitate government infrastructures in land reform and farm restructuring; and (d) the Financial Sector Adjustment Credit (FINSAC) to restructure the banking sector
 8 and make it competitive. Building on the policy framework established under these operations, the proposed Rural Finance Project would provide emergency private farm and agribusiness enterprises access to financial resources to exploit the production and market opportunities being created by the reform programs. 2.20 In addition to the above policy-based operations, IDA's investment resulting in agriculture include the following operations: (a) Sheep Development Project (SDP), which recently became effective, and which aims to privatize, and increase profitability, efficiency and to increase export- orientation in the sheep industry; (b) Agricultural Support Services Project (ASSP), planned for FY98, which would establish adaptive research and advisory services, and support farm restructuring; (c) to be followed by a Land Registration Project in FY99 for emerging private farmers and it would restructure the Ministry of Agriculture and Water Resources to become a service-provider under market-economy conditions; (d) Irrigation Rehabilitation Project (IRP), planned for FY98, which would provide for rehabilitation and maintenance of the major irrigation infrastructure and it would be followed by an On- Farm Irrigation Project in FY2000 to support on-farm irrigation investments and services; (e) People's Initiative Project, planned for FY98, would provide for establishment of an institutional framework for enabling the poorest to have access to financial services; and (f) Rural Finance Project (RFP) would establish an institutional framework for commercially sustainable delivery of credit to private farmers and agribusiness enterprises in the short and long-term. RFP would complement the existing and proposed investments in the agricultural sector under IDA's assistance program. F. BANK EXPERIENCE IN RURAL FINANCE 2.21 Bank experience in supporting rural finance projects has been generally unsatisfactory in the past. Until recently, the Bank's support to rural finance was based on an active role for government through direct interventions such as subsidized interest rates and state-owned and controlled rural financial institutions. This approach did not succeed in achieving the goals of income expansion and poverty alleviation. In recent years, the Bank has adopted a "new approach" in rural finance. This involves a minimalist market-oriented role for government, and places emphasis on creating a favorable policy environment and a supportive legal and regulatory framework for rural financial intermediation. 2.22 The "new approach" has given rise to a growing number of successful rural financial institutions which provide potentially replicable or adaptable methodologies. The most important elements for successful development of a rural finance system include the following: * Appropriate governance, including clearly defined and enforced powers and responsibilities of decision-making entities and individuals; * Management must have autonomy and accountability for operational decisions; * Clients' interests must be fully represented; * Clearly defined strategies and objectives; * Motivated and skilled staff, and staff training and incentives aimed at improved performance; * Innovative low-cost mechanisms and procedures for credit delivery, including mobile- banking in remote areas and group lending; * Positive lending interest rates and high repayment rates; * Risk diversification through lending to both agricultural and non-agricultural activities, and geographic diversification; and * Excellent management information system (MIS) which enables the monitoring of loans, individual client records and staff performance.
 9 2.23 Taking the above experience into account, the proposed project's design features include the following: * KAFC charter provides for operational autonomy through the board of directors and all operational decisions would be made by the management (para. 3.05); * KAFC would be adequately capitalized and would have financial autonomy once it is fully capitalized in the third year of operation (para. 3.07); * KAFC charter provides for eventual participation of the private sector in its ownership (Annex D); * Responsibility and accountability of key management positions in KAFC (including those held by consultants) have been clearly defined (Annex B and C); * KAFC would observe prudential norms that are normally required for commercial financing or banking institutions (para. 3.06); * KAFC's objectives and strategies are commercially oriented and would be constantly updated through revisions of its corporate plans (paras. 3.09 - 3.14); * KAFC would lend at positive interest rates right from the start (para. 3.12); * The expatriate financial controller would design and implement an effective computer-based management information system (Annex C); * SFCOP would be demand-driven and its implementation would be based on beneficiary participation (para. 4.01); * SFCOP would be implemented on a pilot basis to permit some flexibility to learn and eventually lead to establishment of rural financial intermediaries (paras. 3.01 and 4.01); and * innovative low-cost credit delivery mechanisms and procedures, including mobile credit teams in KAFC field offices, screening of loan applications and repayment enforcement by farmers' organizations.
 10 III. THE PROJECT A. PROJECT OBJECTIVES 3.01 The proposed project has two primary objectives: (a) in the short-term, it would establish an interim institutional arrangement for lending to the agricultural and agribusiness sectors which presently have no access to commercial bank credit; and (b) in the medium and long-term, it would provide the basis for developing community-based financial services for the rural population. The former objective would be implemented through the Kyrgyz Agricultural Finance Corporation (KAFC). The latter objective would be implemented through a Small Farmers Credit Outreach Program (SFCOP). This program would be implemented on a pilot basis to permit the necessary flexibility to learn and eventually would lead to the establishment of rural financial intermediaries (RFIs) based on cooperative principles. SFCOP would test specific mechanisms for credit delivery to poor households and develop self-help organizations to facilitate poor household's access to commercial credit and other financial services. These objectives have been translated into monitorable performance indicators (Annex D). B. SUMMARY PROJECT DESCRIPTION 3.02 KAFC Component. Support for KAFC, recently established to replace the moribund Agroprombank (currently under liquidation within the FINSAC framework), would aim to enable KAFC to provide credit on commercial terms to support the ongoing process of farm restructuring, agribusiness enterprise privatization, and private sector development in the rural sector. The project would provide a line of credit of US$13.0 million equivalent, to support KAFC' s lending operations. During the first two years of operation, KAFC would provide short-term/seasonal working capital loans only to private farmers and agribusiness enterprises. Later, it would also provide medium/long-term investment loans for on-farm and agribusiness development, given excellent performance with short-term lending. Support for KAFC's institutional development for capacity building and implementation support is being provided through grant funds from the Swiss Development Cooperation (SDC) and the European Union TACIS. 3.03 SFCOP Component. Support for this pilot component would begin the process of establishing an institutional framework for providing rural financial services on a commercially sustainable basis in the rural areas (para. 1.06). This process would, initially, involve promotion of Farmers' Self-Help Organizations (FSOs) and, eventually during the second phase, the establishment of Rural Financial Intermediaries (RFIs). The promotion of FSOs would involve the following steps: (i) the Borrower would contract KAFC to implement SFCOP; (ii) KAFC would establish a separate Department to administer SFCOP; (iii) the Department would contract two or three Development Entrepreneurs (DEs) to act as financial intermediaries and promoters of FSOs. The DEs would be private firms or NGOs with the requisite qualifications and experience. They will promote the establishment of FSOs and lend the funds administered by KAFC to individual farmers who are members of the FSOs. An FSO would be a (pre-cooperative) group of private farmers pursuing economic objectives, but operating without a joint enterprise. This means that members of an FSO would borrow as individuals through the group. There would no group borrowing or lending under the FSOs. FSOs would place their main emphasis on acquiring economic benefits through self-help in a group and mutual assistance. In contrast to FSOs, RFIs would be fully-fledged cooperatives operating with a joint (cooperative) enterprise capable of carrying out financial intermediation. RFIs would emphasize the acquiring of economic benefits by continuous collaboration organized through a joint enterprise. SFCOP would be limited to providing
 11 support to the promotion of FSOs only, but it would not support the promotion of RFIs which would commence later. The project would support SFCOP's lending program of US$2.0 million equivalent. 3.04 Institutional and Policy Framework. The project would support priority technical assistance under the KAFC and SFCOP components, and promote institutional, legal and policy changes or innovations which would directly enhance successful achievement of the project objectives. Institutional improvements would involve revision of the KAFC charter, adoption of an appropriate corporate and management structure for KAFC, and adoption of appropriate operational policies and procedures for KAFC. Legal improvements would consist of establishing a legal framework to facilitate the development of FSOs into fully-fledged local financial intermediaries. Policy changes would comprise implementation of actions to rationalize the provision of budgetary support to the agricultural credit program. In order to be eligible to this discount, such intermediaries would have to demonstrate: (i) satisfactory management capacity to effectively evaluate loan applications, administer credit to and recover credit from their members; (ii) agree to introduce and implement satisfactory accounting system for lending operations; (iii) agree to assume the on-lending risk on basis of joint and several liability; and (iv) provide tangible and adequate collateral. Sub-loan repayment periods for on-farm investments, farm machinery and equipment, transportation equipment, and agro-processing investments would not exceed the useful life of the investment financed, and, as rule, should not exceed 10 years, including a grace period of no more than three years. Initially, loan applications would be processed in the field offices by mobile credit officers and then submitted to the head office for further review by senior loan officers and loan approval by the Credit Committee or the Board. The adoption of new farm technologies by private farmers would be accelerated by the availability of credit under the RFP. 4.12 Irrigation Rehabilitation Project (IRP) This project, under preparation, would focus on rehabilitating the main irrigation infrastructure (main canals and dams) to restore efficiency and provide adequate water downstream. The availability of credit to private farmers through the RFP would provide
 31 the necessary incentive for private farmers to adopt irrigation-intensive technologies and assure satisfactory economic returns on the upstream investments under the IRP. 4.13 Pilot Demonstration Project (PDP)/Kyrgyz People's Initiative Project (KPIP). The Pilot Demonstration Project is currently under implementation and has provided a learning process on which the proposed KPIP would be based. The PDP has successfully tested and demonstrated that (i) the rural poor can be encouraged to organize themselves into viable self-help organizations; (ii) the poor and disadvantaged households can, as a group, take advantage of opportunities to improve their financial and social well-being. The proposed KPIP would pursue the same objectives as the PDP and it would remain focused on the resource-poor farmers, on average cultivating less than 5 hectares under irrigation or owning a small herd or flock of livestock. The SFCOP under the RFP would use similar mobilization strategies that have proven effective under the PDP, but would focus on a relatively resource-richer target group of farmers (cultivating 10-50 ha and already producing a surplus for the market). Ultimately, the KPIP groups would be expected to "graduate" into FSOs and these, in turn, into RFIs. Thus the step-by - step approach underpinning both KPIP and SFCOP would result into a complementary effort in the long term, despite the difference in target groups between the two programs. 4.14 ADB's Credit Union Project. This project is being proposed by ADB for financing. It would comprise the establishment of a Credit Union System (CUS) with an Apex Union initially to be wholly by the Government and will gradually transfer ownership to credit unions and support for NBK to strengthen its regulatory and supervisory capacity. The CUS program would involve the establishment of 280 credit unions and an Apex Union over a six year period to provide savings and lending services and provides for a credit line of about US$7.0 million to match share capital and savings of credit union members. The performance of the three trial credit unions has experienced several "teething" problems, including slow response by farmers to participate; lack of guidance and training; inadequate savings mobilization from members; inadequate accounting practices; and weak local leadership. These have led to changes in the project design. The CUS would thus aim to create formal cooperative organizations, characterized by a group of members operating through a joint enterprise (i e, the cooperative enterprise) to access savings and lending services. Credit unions would therefore be financial intermediaries right from the start. Under the SFCOP, the initial emphasis would be to access credit through self-help and mutual assistance and trust within the group without operating a joint or cooperative enterprise. The credit unions established under the CUS program would be the last stage of development of individual FSOs under the SFCOP and would not be promoted under the RFP. However, FSOs which mature enough to require the operation of a joint enterprise within two years under the SFCOP, would be advised either to approach KAFC to have access to its group lendingfacility or to apply to the Apex Union and NBK to be registered as members of the CUS. Since both the CUS and SFCOP programs would be demand driven, it is unlikely that they would compete for members, even within the same geographical outreach. Finally, KAFC's group lending facility would be available to all eligible RFIs, including credit unions under the CUS Program. 4.15 Other Rural Credit Schemes. There are several donor and government-sponsored rural credit schemes in the county. The major source of credit is the government credit program which channels budgetary funds through the Rural Credit Cooperatives (RCC), established on the basis of a top-down approach with little or no beneficiary participation. The RCCs, as indicated by the government failure to recover its loans since 1992 (para. 3.28), have been a dismal failure. The RCCs are expected to play a marginal role and disappear with the elimination of the government agricultural credit program at the end of 1999 (para. 3.28). Donor-sponsored rural credit schemes play an insignificant role, in terms of the overall credit supply and private farmer coverage. The major donor-sponsored credit schemes include those operated by EU-TACIS, Mercy Corps, CARITAS, HELVETAS and GTZ and have a total of 4,100 participants to whom they lend less than US$1.5 million equivalent (seasonal credit only) per season. All
 32 these lenders are charging negative interest rates (12 percent/year) and loan recovery on some schemes is less than 60 percent. These distortions would initially affect lending under the RFP. However, both the KAFC and SFCOP lending programs would be based on what has worked or is working in these various credit programs and schemes. The "get-tough" and business-like attitude of KAFC and the DEs would contrast with the less business-like attitude and "grant culture" associated with some of the donors and NGOs involved in the rural credit schemes in the country. The PDP has actually demonstrated that substantial pay-off, in terms of loan recoveries, can be associated with the former attitude.

BENEFITS 5.01 The project would meet an urgent need to develop an efficient system of delivering credit to the emerging private farming and agribusiness sectors. The project would also attempt to create a commercially sustainable system for providing financial services to the rural population in the longer term. The project would complement and enhance the achievement of the CAS objectives (para 2.19) in several ways. By providing access to credit to many private farmers and agribusiness enterprises, who currently do not have such access, the project would enable such farmers and rural enterprises to make use of the production and marketing opportunities that are being created by the government's programs for economic liberalization, enterprise privatization, and farm restructuring. This access to credit would lead to increased efficiency in farm production, agribusiness production and services. In particular, the provision of credit to numerous rural agribusiness enterprises would enable them to participate in the procurement of both farm inputs and products, and facilitate the development of rural competitive markets which are currently lacking and are constraining both quality and quantity of production. Increased and diversified farm and agribusiness production and value would therefore take place, with substantial impact on rural incomes and poverty alleviation. The project would also serve as an effective vehicle for deepening the ongoing government economic reform program and shortening the transition period. For example, by providing access to credit to private small farmers, and by insisting on further farm restructuring action plans as a credit conditionality for family association farms and collective or state farms, the project would accelerate the pace of farm restructuring and privatization of farms. 5.02 The promotion and development of FSOs, as democratic organizations owned and run by members, would have important implications for the process of political and economic decentralization in the country. The local organizations would encourage political and economic empowerment of the local communities. For a country undergoing a transition towards a democratic regime, the project's contribution to political and social stability during the transition period cannot be over-emphasized 5.03 The project would establish the basis for creating a rural finance system to serve the rural communities, including private farmers and rural agribusiness enterprises who are increasingly emerging from the ongoing programs for economic restructuring. The project would use both foreign and local private sector agencies, with government support and financing, to establish a private sector-oriented rural finance system. Both KAFC and SFCOP would establish operating policies and procedures, and banking skills necessary for investment lending and eventually produce a cadre of well-trained and experienced rural finance specialists. These specialists could be employed and together with the successful policies and procedures of KAFC and SFCOP, could be replicate by commercial banks for the benefit of the entire banking sector in the country. Although the KAFC, Department, and DEs are considered as temporary institutions, which would disappear with the cessation of government direct support to the rural finance sector, they are expected to be converted into genuine private sector financial institutions. KAFC and Department could eventually be merged and sold to the private sector (e.g., to become the national apex organizations of all rural financial intermediaries). It is possible that some of the DEs, being part of the private sector in their own right, could form the basis for horizontal and vertical integration by the RFIs at oblast or regional level. In other words, they could become the nuclei for the formation of regional RFIs. 5.04 Lending to private farmers under both the KAFC and SFCOP programs would be closely linked to agricultural advisory services and agricultural marketing (especially input supply). Agricultural advisory service, under the SDP and (later) ASSP, would provide private farmers with farm and financial
 34 management skills in addition to production technology. Linking credit to trade of inputs and crops could be an effective mechanism for minimizing the risk of default. All participants in this credit extension- trade development package would emphasize proper use of credit, sound financial management, and credit repayment discipline as conditions for continued access to institutional credit among borrowers. 5.05 The project would also assure that lenders would assess the environmental effects of sub-loans and make their friendliness to the environment a necessary condition for financing. Farmers and agribusiness enterprises would be required to abide with the environmental requirements prescribed by the national environmental authority for agro-chemical management, soil conservation, irrigation management, and agro-industrial affluent control. 5.06 The project would additionally have other externalities, including significant improvements in rural financial market information and integration of financial markets in the long term. At present, the existence of imperfect information and incomplete markets in the country's rural finance system account for the extremely high cost of providing financial services to rural communities. The development of close lender-borrower relationship between KAFC and farmers' organizations (local RFIs) and agribusiness enterprises, and the establishment of FSOs, owned and operated by the community, would lead to lenders (KAFC and DEs) knowing their customers (members of RFIs and FSOs) better and vice versa. This would lead to improved market transparency and substantial reduction in information cost (e.g., cost of loan screening) and risk management cost. This market transparency would attract other lenders, like commercial banks, to lend to the rural sector from which they currently shy away because of the perceived problems of imperfect information and high risk. This market integration would result in increased lending to the rural sector and also optimal allocation of financial resources between the rural sector and other sectors of the economy. 5.07 Finally, the project would have complementary effects on other investments being undertaken or planned within the agricultural sector (paras. 4.09-4.15) by the Bank under its current CAS. In some cases ( for example, adoption of new technologies by farmers and agribusiness enterprises), optimal returns on these investments would depend on the availability of credit. B. JUSTIFICATION 5.08 Credit Requirements. Despite increasing budget allocations (in nominal terms) by government to the agricultural credit program since 1992 (paras. 3.27 and 3.28), the nascent private farming sector has hardly benefited as these transfers have been targeted to the ex-state and collective farms. These farms are virtually still under the command of the local authorities who continue to be responsible for the credit fund distribution and it is not clear to what extent the funds even reached these farms. Consequently, much of private farming in the country has had no access to credit to purchase seasonal production inputs or capital equipment. Consumption of essential farm inputs, such as fertilizers, agricultural chemicals, and veterinary medicines and drugs has substantially contracted. As a result, farm production, productivity and profitability for both major crops and livestock have dramatically fallen since 1992, except for wheat, potatoes, and vegetables in the last two years. Estimating demand for agricultural credit in an economy undergoing a unique transition like the Kyrgyz Republic and where the concept of credit has been highly distorted is a daunting exercise. However, using farm data, the cash outlays (requirement) for producing the major crops and livestock among private farms the cash requirements of the farming sector were estimated. used as a proxy for credit needs. Applying two generally used rules of thumb, the amount of credit requirement (not demand) of the farming sector was estimated. The rules of thumb, commonly used in estimating credit requirements are (i) agricultural sector's credit requirement in a given production period normally represent 10 percent of the sector's

The ADB survey (1996) estimated the demand for working capital and longer term investments at US$30.0 million. A study on agribusiness financing requirements done during the preparation of this project revealed that both working capital and investment finance were critical to the restart and rehabilitation of existing privatized agribusiness enterprises. Entry onto input supply and farm product markets is being effectively hindered by lack of access to working capital credit by new private agribusiness enterprises. As a result, the anticipated recovery in the agribusiness sector is not materializing following the massive privatization effort in the sector. Indeed production of processed food has consistently fallen since 1990 and in general production in 1996 was less than one-third of 1990. Access to working capital among agribusiness enterprises would restart the recovery in the sector and make both farm markets and agribusiness product markets more competitive and efficient. These developments would have positive income and employment effects in the medium term. Several recent farm studies, including the Farm Profitability Assessment Study (September, 1996) and the crop and livestock budgets prepared during the preparation of this project, indicate that the Kyrgyz Republic has comparative advantage in the production of its major commodities. These include wheat, maize, potatoes, cotton, wool, and dairy cattle. Although farmgate prices for most of these commodities are still well below international parity prices, farmers' profitability in the production of these commodities has been generally improving and this improvement is likely to remain strong in the near future as local markets become more competitive during the implementation of this project. Mixed farming, consisting of crop and livestock production, is widely practiced in the country, except at higher mountain elevations (e.g., most of Naryn Oblast) where sheep farming is predominant. This mixed farming system gives private farmers reasonable risk diversification, balanced cash flow, and flexibility in responding to changes in market signals. 5.11 To illustrate the financial impact of the project on farm profitability, financial rates of return (IRRs) were estimated for four farm models which are considered to be representative of the farming system and cropping patterns in the country. The "without" situation is represented by the current
 36 production structure in the representative private farms, in terms of yields and cost structure which face a critical credit supply constraint. As a result of this constraint, inadequate working capital results in underutilization of available land and in non-optimal adoption of inputs packages, or no use of modern inputs. Under these circumstances, for example, farmers choose to use fertilizers alone without weedicides in the production of wheat or grains. These decisions by farmers affect both yields and production. The "with" situation postulates adequate availability of working capital through credit. This enables framers to make full use of the available land and to adopt optimal inputs packages in line with technical recommendations. Also, through increased competition and efficiency in the input delivery system under the project, input prices would decline by about 15 percent. SUSTAINABILITY 5.14 The project would be implemented, to a large extent, by private sector agencies (DEs, and FSOs) and commercially-oriented public institutions (KAFC and Department) with government support and initial funding. Once established, both types of institutions would generally be able to operate on a sustainable basis. Despite the presence of externalities, asymmetric information, incomplete markets,
 37 and the project's focus on poverty reduction, the rural finance system would be developed on a cost recovery basis, except for the initial costs of technical assistance and training. All financial intermediaries participating in the project would charge interest rates that would be positive in real terms and cover the cost of funds. The productivity and financial gains generated by the project would provide incentives for the farmers' organizations and the KAFC to consolidate and expand their newly acquired assets and roles. As the farmers' organizations develop into financially strong intermediaries, it is likely that they would begin to integrate vertically into an apex financial institution. They could do so by buying out any remaining government ownership in KAFC. The Department, once it has successfully realized its mandate, could be converted into a department specializing in lending to small farmers and agribusiness enterprises. The sustainability of the DEs, which would be private sector agencies, would be governed by their responses to market changes and their ability to remain competitive. Some of the DEs could be transformed into regional financial intermediaries, exclusively owned by local farmers' organizations and rural agribusiness enterprises. D. IMPACT ON POVERTY 5.15 The project's SFCOP would directly target the poor farm households at, or slightly above the poverty line. This segment of the poor has been increasing and accounting for the rise in the proportion of households below the poverty line (para. 1.06). Most of the rural poor are "temporarily poor" because they have two assets which are critical to agricultural production: land and labor. Access to credit would enable farm households to make full use of these primary resources and increase their production and incomes. The farm cash flows and financial rates of returns estimated above show that increases in both production and incomes would be substantial (Table 5.2). By helping this segment of the poor to increase both their cash incomes and food security through increased farm productivity and production, the project would effectively reduce the proportion of households below the poverty line. It would also help reduce the poverty gap, which doubled during 1993-1996. By financing agribusiness enterprises, production and employment in the sector would increase and, at the same time, farm product markets would become more competitive, creating remunerative market opportunities for farmers. E. FISCAL IMPACT 5.16 The impact of the project on the government budget would be positive in the long term. During the first year of operation, Government would be required to allocate about som 7.4 million as share capital contribution for KAFC and som 250,000 for the Department administrative budget. If, however, MAWR and RA would be able to collect a large share of the outstanding debt from farmers, government contributions to KAFC and the Department would be funded by these collections. This would eliminate the traditional dependence of agricultural lending on the government budget. Subsequent government contributions to the share capital of KAFC would be through proceeds of the proposed IDA Credit (para. 3.07). After 1999, the government agricultural credit program, which has been a major drain on the budget, would be phased out. Lending to agriculture under the project would largely be financed outside the budget, mainly through donor funds, domestic commercial borrowing by KAFC, and credit reflows. F. RISKS 5.17 The project has high risks. The major risks consist of: (i) institutional innovations, (ii) fragility of farm profitability inherent in a nascent private farming sector under transition; (iii) political interference; (iv) continuation of the Government agricultural support program; and (v) unwillingness to repay by borrowers.
 38 5.18 Risks of Institutional Innovations. All local institutions and staff involved in implementing the project would be new and they would adopt credit delivery mechanisms which are yet to be proven under Kyrgyz conditions. These risks would be minimized by: (i) employing experienced technical assistance from the private sector to manage the key institutions (KAFC and DEs); (ii) emphasizing practical training for staff and members of key institutions; and (iii) adopting an implementation strategy that limits the project scope, decentralizes project implementation, and provides for continuous feedback and adjustment (para.. 4.01). 5.19 Fragile Farm Profitability. Private farming is still a transitional phenomenon in the Kyrgyz Republic. Profitability of most commodities in private farms is still generally depressed by market failures inherent in the transition process. There has been, however, some remarkable recovery in the profitability of wheat, potatoes, and vegetables in 1996. But, even this is still extremely fragile. A more widespread and robust recovery in farm profitability would be necessary for ensuring demand for credit and minimizing the risk of defaults by borrowers. This would require extensive adoption of productivity-enhancing technologies by farmers and the development of competitive domestic markets. The project would assist farmers in this adoption process and it would also assist agribusiness enterprises to participate more actively in farm product and inputs markets to enhance competition. 5.20 Political Interference. Government support and funding to the project could engender the risk of political interference. KAFC, in particular, could be under political pressure to expand its lending operations beyond its management capacity and thus compromise its autonomy and prudential management. To mitigate this risk, provisions have been made in its charter for private sector representation on KAFC Board and for a strong and capable management team right from its inception. In addition, the Board would be expected to honor its commitment to oversee the implementation of KAFC's approved corporate plan, lending policies, and procedures. 5.21 Government Agricultural Support Program. Continuation of the Government agricultural credit program, even after reaching agreement on the rationalization measures (para. 3.28), would constitute a major risk to the viability of KAFC. The Government might have no political muscle to implement and enforce the agreed measures. In addition, until the Government acts decisively and resolutely in enforcing the agreed measures, borrowers would expect the continuation of the credit non- repayment culture nurtured by Agroprombank and the Government credit programs. In the event of this risk becoming eminent, KAFC would take extra measures to increase its institutional capacity to expand its lending operations to enable Government to channel its agricultural support through it and thereby eliminate a separate subsidized Government credit program. 5.22 Unwillingness to Pay by Borrowers. The legacy of Agroprombank and Government credit program has nurtured a credit non-repayment culture even when borrowers have the ability to repay. This will haunt KAFC and SFCOP. The likelihood of this happening would be minimized by the "get-tough" and business-like approach and refusal to forgive debt to be adopted by both KAFC and SFCOP. In addition, collective responsibility for loan screening and loan repayment enforcement should gradually prove effective, particularly for SFCOP, in getting borrowers to repay. G. ENVIRONMENTAL IMPACT 5.23 The environmental impact of the project would be negligible. The potentially adverse environmental impact resulting from the use of agricultural chemicals and fertilizers would, however, be reduced by the use modern application methods, better equipment, and training in application and equipment use by the extension staff. The liberalization of prices for fertilizers and chemicals has

doc.abstracts: The Rural Finance Project has two primary objectives: 1) in the short-term, it will establish an interim institutional arrangement for lending to the agricultural and agribusiness sectors which presently have no access to commercial bank credit; and 2) in the medium and long-term, it will provide the basis for developing community-based financial services for the rural population. The project is comprised of the following components: (i) Kyrgyz Agricultural Finance Corporation (KAFC) line of credit; (ii) Small Farmers' Credit Outreach Program (SFCOP) line of credit; (iii) KAFC technical assistance; (iv) SFCOP technical assistance; (v) training for KAFC and SFCOP; and (vi) support for administrative budgets.
